Another game of genre: „let’s put maximum abstract elements to the rulebook and let’s pretend they all work together”. But all of this is simply a fake to keep euro geeks excited. After dozens of similar heavy non-sense euros I worked out my own strategy to play such games and not get crazy. I don’t calculate anything because in such overabundance of abstract factors it’s not possible to play consciously. How can you evaluate in the middle of the game whether the advance on one track is more profitable than erecting the building? You can’t. Especially when almost each element of the game may give you VPs. So, when I play such games I don’t calculate anything. I just do what I can afford, what the game offers best at given moment and what doesn’t require too much thinking to keep downtime on minimum level (read: to end up this nightmare as quickly as possible). And I observe the final results. If I win when I play with euro geeks who calculate every single move than I know the game sucks. This one I won! Full stop.

P.S. And you know what’s the funniest thing? After 1 hour of listening to the rulebook explanation I gave up last 15 minutes due to overall boredom and exhaustion. So I didn’t learn how to use assistants and synergy tokens. Never mind. They both turned out to be perfectly useless for my victory. 15 minutes of my live saved :-)

What I like:
- I can see how the game might appeal to players who enjoy sandbox-style Euros with lots of paths to explore. There’s a sense of freedom in how you approach the game, and some of the card synergies can be satisfying when they click.

What I dislike:
- It’s just too much. Too many subsystems, too many effects, too many icons, too many steps to do anything. It’s not that I mind complexity — but here, it feels bloated. Like the design kept adding layers without asking whether they actually improved the experience.
- The game falls into that “standard Euro with a generic theme” category. The setting is barely there, and the mechanics don’t do much to bring it to life. The combat system especially feels abstract and disconnected — powerful, yes, but thematically flat.
- The quest action feels underpowered. It’s supposed to be one of the more thematic parts of the game, but it rarely feels worth the action. Meanwhile, combat is often the most efficient path, which just reinforces how off-balance the systems can be.

Final thoughts:
Maracaibo tries to be a grand, sprawling Euro with lots of replayability and strategic depth. And to be fair, some players love that. But for me, it ended up feeling like a collection of half-connected systems, all competing for attention. There’s ambition here, but not enough cohesion. I respect what it’s trying to do — I just don’t have the patience for it anymore.

Love the card play and the "freedom" of the rondel, though one gets the notion that fighting for the influence tracks is possibly too important while things like quests not important enough and that the former is always a strong strategy and the latter always a weak one, making several turns throughout the game feel mechanical and one-note. I've not played nearly enough to make a total determination but fighting definitely seems dominant. Sometimes insurmountable. But it could be similar to something like e.g. military strength in THROUGH THE AGES - yes, clearly very strong, and you will get destroyed if you ignore it, but you can find many other mainlines to victory as long as you keep pace (somewhat) and don't fall \too\ far behind. The "disc removal" mechanism is one I admittedly like a lot (though it was done with much greater effect already in GREAT WESTERN TRAIL). End of round procedure is a little clunky. Some of the various card synergies are fascinating if you can pull them off successfully.

Enjoyable but mostly dull and unremarkable rondel point salad tableau building race, for all of the rules and fiddly setup the game itself is fairly simple and as a result the decisions are too obvious and straight forward to be an interesting optimization puzzle. Update 2:

Great Western Trail’s younger, more ambitious brother. It’s got systems upon systems that layer on top of one another in very interesting ways, and the core gameplay loop is really pretty exciting for a euro. Typical of chunky games like this, there are dozens of strategies you could try, and it seems to me that it probably has a lot of replayability for a low-interaction affair.

It’s a perfectly good euro game, but it gives me a similar feeling as GWT does, and it takes longer, has more rules, turns are way slower, and it has less player interaction (which GWT doesn’t have much of to begin with). Maracaibo’s theme is also much, much worse. It’s colonial Caribbean setting does nothing to engage with its subject matter, which makes you wonder why they chose such a problematic theme in the first place. I mean, it kind of comes across as a fun tropical romp, but you didn’t need to set it in this time and place to get that across! It’s just kind of weird and comes across as a bit lazy, IMO. The rest of the design definitely isn’t lazy - it’s actually a bit too much. An elegant euro game, this is not.

The only thing I think that it has over GWT is the tableau building, which can be really interesting and fun, but I don’t think there will ever be a time that I’ll play this over GWT.

My rating for it is still soft. Sometimes I find myself really agonizing over my decisions (in a good way) and others I'm either tuning out (or getting frustrated) because the game is running on the long side (even though we've trimmed off at least thirty-minutes from our first few plays). Like Great Western Trail before it, Maracaibo is a rondel game. This time it's set in the Caribbean, but it's a pasted on theme so don't expect it to give the sense of swashbuckling and daring-do. Even combat is abstracted to moving disks and placing cubes. Playing using the campaign cards adds a bit of variation between games, but I don't find they add all that much to the game. In fact, they tend to slow down the game and this offsets the plus they get for novelty. All in all, I do enjoy Maracaibo more than Great Western Trail, but as Pfister's games go, I still prefer Mombasa.

El juego de rondel que más disfruto por las diferentes posibilidades que se establecen en cada ruta, ampliadas por la configuración variable del tablero en cada partida. Además, la variedad y la versatilidad de las cartas lo convierten en uno de los juegos de desarrollo de cartas que más disfruto en todos los sentidos. Todas las acciones son divertidas y enlazarlas y conseguir bonos y recompensas de final de partida es muy satisfactorio, así como el juego mental a la hora de desatar la ronda.

* LO MEJOR: La infinita variabilidad en cuanto a cartas y configuración del tablero.

* LO PEOR: El track de naciones está desequilibrado hacia arriba y el de la jungla hacia abajo.

Maracaibo est un jeu de stratégie complexe offrant une grande variété de possibilités. Le mélange de mécaniques, comme le placement d’ouvriers, la gestion de main et la construction de moteur, en fait un titre riche et profond. Le mode histoire apporte une touche narrative intéressante, modifiant le plateau de partie en partie pour une immersion accrue.

Cependant, l’ergonomie souffre de quelques défauts. Le plateau personnel, les cartes ou le plateau principal surchargés d’icônes, peuvent être déroutant au début. De plus, la qualité des illustrations laisse à désirer. Ces éléments peuvent freiner l’apprentissage initial. La mise en place est aussi très longue.

Le jeu offre une grande liberté d’action, ce qui peut mener à des parties assez longues, surtout à quatre joueurs. L’interaction est principalement indirecte, chaque joueur développant sa propre stratégie mais la mécanique des nations sera commune à tous les joueurs. Une excellente idée, il faudra s’adapter aux autres joueurs. Cela va de même pour le tempo du jeu qui sera donné par les joueurs.

En somme, Maracaibo est un excellent jeu pour les joueurs expérimentés, prêts à investir du temps pour maîtriser ses subtilités. Si l’ergonomie perfectible ne vous rebute pas, vous apprécierez la profondeur de ce titre et la richesse de ses choix stratégiques.

Maracaibo adopts a similar round structure to the excellent Great Western Trail, where players move along a track, deciding when and where to stop in order to perform various actions. However, Maracaibo is more focused on card play rather than deck-building and introduce a bit more interraction trought majority game play. It is a highly refined game, likely complex to explain, but the theme is engaging and immersive. Mr. Pfister continues to solidify his reputation as one of the top game designers of all time, with Maracaibo adding to his impressive portfolio of standout titles (including Mombasa).

A classic Pfister design with a mix of rondel movement, multi-use cards and tableau building. The game has a tight economy but feels open in terms of strategical options. The multi-use cards make for a delightful hand management puzzle, as you will need to consider how best to utilize your hand base on the state of your economy and position of your ship. The twist of a round ending (often prematurely) for everyone when one player reaches the end of the rondel, creates a lot of player tension as you will have to keep an eye out for how fast your opponents go. Love the use of legacy tiles to ensure each game plays differently from the next. Painful set-up aside, this is a masterpiece I am always excited to play.

Excellent economic game. The first couple of plays might feel overwhelming because there's so much to take in. As the captain of your ship you are free to set the course, pick your contracts, goals, allies and even upgrade your ship to suit your needs. Many of the mechanisms are interconnected but it all works together well and there are always multiple strategies you can begin pursuing.

The story mode serves the game well, not taking the focus off the core gameplay, but slowly revealing new elements to make every game feel just a bit different, which keeps frequent players on their toes.
